addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord high Treasurer of England.

22 Martij
1592
M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.63r
May it please yo
r
good L. Having written of late
to
S
r
Robert Cecill
,
at w
ch
his H. will impart to yo
r
L.
I have
e lesse at this p
nt
to signifie unto yow.
Count Maurices
purpose to surprise
Gertrudenbergh
hath had some impeachements, for w
ch
it hath not bin
attempted. Howbeit his forces were landed fower
daies sins: and
e Est part of
e towne called Langh-
straete is kept by
Count Hohenlo
, w
t
2 regiments of
foote, and certaine horse, to
e number of 200 and more,
who hath used great expedition in qartering his people,
and hath planted already 10 peeces of batterie, w
ch
I
thinke, as this day, shall play upon
e towne. Count
Maurice doth beseige
e west part, but hath nether yet
entrenched, nor begonne any worke, wherof we knowe
not heere
e reason. But by cause of his slacknes,
and for
at there have messengers passed betweene him
and
e Governo
r
Mons
r
de Magires, it is conceaved
that
e gouverno
r
doth give some hope of composition:
whereto it is thought he will yelde
e rather, because
that
Mons
r
de Waterdike
, who hath bin gouverno
r
once
before, is nowe againe appointed by letters out of
Spaine,
w
ch
discontenteth exceedingly Mons
r
de Magires,
and all
e souldiers of his garrison. This is as
much as is p
nt
ly reported. This
Councel
of estate
hath conferred heere of late w
t
divers com-
missaries of this contrey, about
e reformation of abu-
ses in their musters, aswell of
e companies
at are
paied by her
Ma
tie
as of their owne intertenment.
That w
ch
they doe suppose to be amisse in
e Englishe,
and to empeache
e concurrence of
e Commissaries
of bothe contreis, in taking
e Musters jointly together,
they have exhibited in wriitng, to
e end I should
send it: as w
t
all they desire,
at for
e better perfour-
mance of those services, their last placart of Musters
may be practised by her Hig
es
Commissaries: and if it shall be found,
at there is any thing
in it ether against
e Treatie, or otherwise faultie in w
at
respect soever, they will enter
into conference, and willingly redresse it.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Ma
r
22 1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
